bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April, 20, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas writes about his administration of sanitary affairs in the Canal Zone and political machinations.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April, 20, 1905
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, CANAL ZONE
April 20, 1905
Maj. J. R. Kean,
Medical Corps, U.S.A.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
Your letters of the 3rd and the 10th received.
It seems to me that you and Gen. O'Reilly are very bloody
minded in being so eager to get off the heads of LaGarde
and Spratling, but seriously I think you are in the wrong.
I think it would be very poor policy to move in the matter
until I meet Judge Magoon and know something of my position.

What I would do, if I acted on my own judgment,
would be this:

There is no pressing hurry in the matter and the
question of a few weeks will make very little difference. I
would wait until I had seen Judge Magoon, found out just what
my position was and what his powers were, lay the matter be-
for him and find out whether I would have his support. If I
found that he was going to support me I would then write
LaGarde and Spratling, telling them that, in my opinion, it
was best for the work at large that their connection with
it should be severed, and give them the opportunity of taking
action on their own part. I would do this because it would
be less of a reflection upon them and because it is what I
would like to have done to me in similar circumstances.
2:-
If they did not act I would then write officially to Judge
Magoon, recommending the change. For me to put in an official
application now, not knowing how Judge Magoon would act,
I think would be very unwise. If he should not support me
it would leave me in the position of having two of my chief men
on my hands openly antagonistic, and that would certainly
weaken my discipline a great deal.

You write saying that I can communicate directly with
Gen. O'Reilly and Judge Magoon. I have no official information
of this. As far as I know I am still under General Davis
as Governor.

These are my reasons, and I still think them very good,
for not making application for the change now: I think
if I made the application it should go through Gen. Davis,
and he would merely forward it for the action of the commission;
in Spratling's case I am quite sure entering an emphatic
disapproval. With regard to LaGarde I believe he would support
me. If Gen. O'Reilly thinks differently I herewith forward
a letter to Judge Magoon, asking for the change, but unless
Gen. O'Reilly is sure that it will receive Judge Magoon's support,
I know it will be a mistake to put it in. Rest assured that
I understand conditions down here better than either of you do
and know about what I am talking.

Now as for Balch. I do not know what you and the
General know about him, but I do not believe either of you
know as much as I do. I roomed with him for two months down here
and had to listen to him every day for that time. His great
fault is that he talks morning, noon and night, Otherwise
3:-
he is a capable man.

I do not understand from the President's letter that
the government is to have a purchasing officer; as I under-
stand it we are to merely have charge of our supplies after
they get down here. Balch is honest, capable, energetic, and
knows our wants and conditions down here and if Mr. Shonts
wants a purchasing agent for medical supplies, I do not believe
he could get as good a one as Balch. Certainly he would
do a great deal better than the men who have heretofore done
our purchasing. I think it would be very much better, as the
work is in the War Department, to have our medical purveyor
do the purchasing, but I would a great deal rather have Balch
do it than to have it done as it is at present, but I have
no particular interest in Balch and do not intend to make my-
self a martyr for his sake and shall not urge him upon Judge
Magoon. But here again I think you and Gen. O'Reilly are
making up your minds without knowing the circumstances of the
case. You can't, in Washington, judge for me down here. It
is out of the question. Balch is a man of tolerably
influencial political connections and a great talker, and
while his letter is of the same character as Reed's, much
exaggerated, he has data for everything he has said and could
use it very disagreeably. I think it would be a very good
piece of policy to tuck him away in some position where he
could do good work and where it would be to his interest not
to talk, but this concerned more the old Commission and I
don't see that it is of much importance one way or the other
now.

What I am grumbling about is that you and Gen. O'Reilly
sit up in Washington criticising my soft heart, meaning my
soft head, without knowing a damn thing about it (pardon the
expression). Now I flatter myself that I am running this
job pretty well. I am sorry the Secretary has formed an
unfavorable opinion of me, but I rather think that is a result
of the position I had to take, and I believe that if I remain
here six months he will have changed his opinion. He knew
nothing in the world of the Sanitary Department; did not ask
10 words about it when he was down here. He derived his
ideas entirely from Gen. Davis, and Gen. Davis' ideas were
formed very naturally from his own standards. He and I
differed in sanitary matters; he thought he knew all about it;
I thought I knew all about it. As we were diametrically opposed
in many things one of us had to be wrong. The Secretary
heard his side of the question and naturally formed an un-
favorable opinion of my work. If he had heard me alone he
would have formed an equally unfavorable opinion of Gen.
Davis' work. I am merely referring to the General in his
official capacity now. He is a fine old fellow and I admire
him and like him. I do not know anybody whom I look upon,
taking all in all, as a higher type of man, but he is not a good
administrator, and, in my opinion, not a good sanitarian, and I
think it greatly to my advantage that he is not to remain as
Governor.

I am inclined to think that the General has a very
much higher opinion of me as an executive now than he had
three months ago. I saw the storm coming and warned him time
and time again. When I took charge, as things developed,
5:-
I either had to acquiesce in the sanitary ideas of Gen. Davis
and Mr. Grunsky, or be constantly advising pretty strongly
in directions they did not like. I could see, from Cubian
experience, that in following the tack they were we would be
exposed to a great deal of just criticism, and that to save myself
I must get on record as advising differently. If I had joined
in and acquiesced in all proposed I would have been thought
a good sanitarian, but my career on the Isthmus would have
now been ended. As it is, I am looked upon as a poor
administrator, but still I am here, have accomplished the
sanitary results I hoped for when I first came down, and these
facts will very soon be recognized. I think,if you cast
reflections upon the r consistency of my cardiac organ, you
might at any rate give me credit for good judgment and
diplomacy in my year down here, and balance my mushy heart
but saying something about good firm cerebral tissue.

And now as to the positions here. Our force is full
of ranking men; I have as many as I need, and cannot use any
more. What I want is the young men who can get out on the
line and do professional service. I do not want any more men
that I cannot order around anywhere. For Ross's place I have
recommended Carter. Carter has been doing the work since
Ross left. I do not think you could give me a better man from
the whole corps. I have asked for Straub with the idea of
putting him up there. Stark's place as Health Officer
of Colon is at present filled by Wheeler, who I think is doing
the work very well, and all the lower positions caused by
these changes have been filled by promotion. If Spratling goes
7:- 6
I intend to put Curl in his place. If LaGarde goes I shall
need somebody either in his place or Straub's. Now while
you and Gen. O'Reilly know the men of our corps very much
better than I do, I am not so sure that you know as well as
I do the kind of men I need here; the fact is I know you don't.
We are in the worst political kettle down here you every struck.
My immediate success and reputation will depend altogether
upon the personal impression I can make upon Judge Magoon, as
they have depended in the past upon the personal impression
I made upon Gen. Davis, so that of any one quality in the
higher offices in my Department is very much the most important.

I know MuCcullough well and know just what kind of a
man he is. I could rely upon him for support just as I do
upon Carter, and as for work, I flatter myself that I know
Latin-American municipal sanitation about as well as anybody
can. That may sound vain, but I think I am getting it down
pat, and I do not want any man who will make anybody clean
up his back yard; I want him to persuade him to clean up his
backyard; that is the key to the business. My ideal Health
Officer of Panama would be Furbush if I could get him.

Tell Gen. O'Reilly that in my opinion he need not be
anxious about the work down here. It has been accomplished;
I believe yellow fever has been eradicated, and I believe
malaria has been controlled. As evidence of this I advance
the health conditions of a considerable force of men who
have been down here now a year, something like an average of
4000 (we have at present nearly 9000 on the rolls), with only
3 or 4 deaths from yellow fever and a death rate from all
8:- 7
causes of less than 15 per thousand. If we could can keep it down to
that the first year, I do not see why the same methods will
not keep it down for the 2nd year, and the third, and the fourth.
That it is not accidental one can see by comparing it with the
first year of French work in which the French report a death
rate of 67 per thousand, but I think I have pretty good
evidence to know that it was considerably over 100 per
thousand. There is no reasonable cause for this except the
sanitary precautions we have taken, and in six months from
now, as the Secretary of War gradually recognizes these things,
I think he will do me justice in the premises and give me
credit for good administration in about as difficult a position
as I think a man could have.

I am deeply grateful for the backing Gen. O'Reilly
has given me with Secretary Taft, but I have made many
sacrifices in the last four months (you can probably imagine
what they were) to stay here. Every inclination was to ask
to be relieved, and it was always not entirely clear in which
direction duty pointed, but as things have turned out I am
glad I stayed. I look forward to much pleasanter service
under the new order of things. I think now that I have data
to show that we have accomplished all I every expected to accom-
plish and all that probably can be accomplished in the way
of sanitation on the Isthmus. Of course it would be more
satisfactory, if things run smoothly, to demonstrate it for
another year, but I feel pretty “cockey”. I certainly will
not stand any such siege in the coming year as I went through
during the last.

Now I think I have covered all the ground I started
in to do. It is a legal holiday and still, the martyr to
duty that I am, I got up this morning, rode through chaparelle
12 miles to discuss with an engineer the non- advisability
of locating a hotel in a swamp; got back for breakfast, came
down to the office and have been writing this letter ever since.
I feel better. I feel as though I had let off considerable
steam, and so I come to the real gist of the letter with more
pleasure, that is to urge you to come along down, come right
to my house, and I will give you a good room and we will take
you into our mess. There are several things I would like
to talk to you about.

Please remember me most cordially to all in the office,
Gen. O'Reilly and Mrs. Kean.

Mrs. Gorgas' health has been making rapid improvement.
In her last letter she thought she might sail from New York
about April 25th. Maybe you and she can come down in the same
steamer.
div1.closer:
Sincerely your friend, W. C. Gorgas.
Chief Sanitary Officer. Letter dated Apr- 20 -
C.A.L. Reed
